resources.string: this is where the description of this place will go
Kaiseki ryori has its origin in the traditional tea ceremony, but later evolved into an elaborate dining style popular among aristocratic circles.
Whereas kaiseki developed out of the affluence of the aristocrats, shojin ryori developed from the austerity of Buddhist monks.
Obanzai Ryori is the traditional home style cooking of Kyoto. It is made up of multiple small dishes that are usually quite simple to prepare.
\"Kawayuka, or Kawadoko as it is known outside of central Kyoto, is the summer pasttime of dining outdoors on temporary platforms built over flowing water. \"
Sento Imperial Palace is a secondary palace complex across from the Kyoto Imperial Palace in Kyoto Imperial Park.
Shugakuin Imperial Villa was built in the 17th century by Emperor Gomizuno and is now managed by the Imperial Household Agency.
The Toei Uzumasa Eigamura (also known as Kyoto Studio Park or Movie Land.) is a film set and theme park in one.
Katsura Imperial Villa is one of the finest examples of Japanese architecture and garden design.
Ginkakuji (Silver Pavilion) is a Zen temple along Kyoto\'s eastern mountains (Higashiyama).
Kiyomizudera (literally \"Pure Water Temple\") is one of the most celebrated temples of Japan.
Daigoji is an important temple of the Shingon sect of Japanese Buddhism and a designated world heritage site.
\"Tofukuji (東福寺, Tōfukuji) is a large Zen temple in southeastern Kyoto that is particularly famous for its spectacular autumn colors. \"
the festival of Yasaka Shrine, is the most famous festival in Japan. It takes place over the entire month of July.
\"flower and light road\", is a set of illumination events that take place in the Higashiyama District of Kyoto in March and the Arashiyama district of Kyoto in December.

Aoi Matsuri takes place every May 15. The festival\'s main attraction is a large parade in Kyoto, in which over 500 people dressed in the aristocratic style of the Heian Period (794-1185) walk from the Imperial Palace to the Kamo Shrines.

The Jidai Matsuri is a festival that takes place every year on October 22, the anniversary of the foundation of Kyoto. It consists of a large parade that travels from the Imperial Palace to Heian Shrine
